   subcortical white matter as described above, more conspicuous on the
   right frontal lobe, consistent with the previously demonstrated
   thromboembolic ischemic changes, and there is no evidence of
   hemorrhagic transformation, mass,mass effect, or shifting of the
   normally midline structures. Persistent prominent sulci at the left
   frontal region, followup in this area is recommended. If there is any
   clinical concern related with new ischemic area, correlation with MRI
   is recommended if clinically warranted.
   - repeat Echo: Overall left ventricular systolic function is severely
   depressed (LVEF= 20-25%).  There is a very small pericardial effusion,
   no signs of tamponade.  Compared with the prior study (images reviewed)
   of [**2184-3-15**], ejection fraction is now severely depressed. The right
   ventricle, although not well seen, is dilated and hypokinetic. There is
   a small amount of pericardial fluid seen adjacent to the right atrium,
   without evidence of tamponade physiology.
   - MRI of C-spine and head: 1. Limited study due to motion. 2. No
   definite brainstem or cord signal abnormality. 3. Mild to moderate
   spinal canal stenosis at C3-4, with probable at least moderate neural
   foraminal narrowing at this level as well, though evaluation of the
   neural foramina is markedly limited due to motion.
   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval
   development of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive,
   asystolic, and pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   #Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: The first documented rhythm
   was PEA.  patient was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing CPR and
   NaHCO3 and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome
   during the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause.  Lactate during the code was 8.1.  he is currently being
   supported on levophed and fluids.  CE was elevated as expected, but not
   down trending.  He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of
   head.  New RIJ was started but femoral TL was not pulled (1 positive
   blood culture from the femoral site
 GPC in clusters).
   -vancomycin, zosyn
   -f/u bld, urine cx
   -head imaging pending clinical improvement.
   -c-spine MRI pending clinical improvement
   -need to get LP when warmed
   -trend lactate (presistently elevated to 5.1
 likely [**1-20**] to peripheral
   vasoconstriction).
   .
   #Respiratory status: oxygenating well on current settings,
   hyperventilating as well.
   - on vent continue current settings
   .
   #Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.29/30/79.  likely due to cardiac
   disfunction, poor forward flow.
   - cont. cooling protocol
   - maintain pressors
   - consider addition of ionotropic support (dopa?)
   .
   #Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- LP
   .
   #embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right femoral line
   # Communication: family
   # Code: Full
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)
 HYPOTHERMIA
 FEVER (HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA, NOT FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN)
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

   Prophylaxis:

   Stress ulcer:

   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old man admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of fevers and hypotension. He has a history of coronary artery disease and was previously admitted with a fever of unknown origin. During his current admission, he developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes, became unresponsive, and pulseless, requiring resuscitation. He is currently being supported with levophed and fluids, and is on a cooling protocol.

The patient has several ongoing medical issues, including:

* Fever of unknown origin, which has trended down but is still present
* Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation
* Embolic stroke, for which he is being treated with aspirin and pravastatin
* Hypothyroidism, for which he is being monitored but not treated at this time
* Adrenal nodules, for which he is being monitored but not treated at this time
* Chronic kidney disease, stage III, which is stable
* Hyperlipidemia, for which he is being treated with a statin

Potential Medical Complications:

* Sepsis, due to the patient's ongoing fever and metabolic acidosis
* Cardiac dysfunction, due to the patient's history of coronary artery disease and the presence of a pericardial effusion
* Respiratory failure, due to the patient's ongoing hyperventilation and the presence of a small pericardial effusion
* Neurological deficits, due to the patient's embolic stroke
* Infection, due to the presence of a positive blood culture from the femoral site
* Metabolic derangements, due to the patient's ongoing metabolic acidosis and the presence of a lactate level of 5.1

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's current condition is unstable, and he requires ongoing supportive care in the ICU. He will continue to be monitored for signs of sepsis, cardiac dysfunction, respiratory failure, and neurological deficits. He will also continue to receive treatment for his embolic stroke, and will be monitored for signs of infection. His metabolic derangements will be closely monitored, and he will be treated with cooling protocol and pressors as needed.

The patient's plan includes:

* Continued cooling protocol and pressors as needed
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and cardiac dysfunction
* Treatment for his embolic stroke
* Monitoring for signs of infection
* Monitoring for signs of metabolic derangements
* Ongoing supportive care in the ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old man admitted with fevers and hypotension, later found unresponsive and pulseless, with a documented PEA rhythm. He has a history of CAD, and his current condition is complicated by embolic hemorrhagic strokes, fever of unknown origin, and possible vasculitis or lupus.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.1°F (38.4°C)
* Heart rate: 58 bpm
* Blood pressure: 104/50 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 17 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%

The patient has undergone extensive workup for FUO, including blood cultures, urine cultures, and imaging studies, but the etiology of his fever remains unknown. He has been treated with antibiotics, but the fever has not resolved.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 15.3 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 10.6 g/dL
* Platelet count: 188 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.2 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.10 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 5.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.7 g/dL
* LDH: 684 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 6.9 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CT of the head: scattered areas of low attenuation in the subcortical white matter, consistent with thromboembolic ischemic changes
* MRI of the C-spine and head: limited study due to motion, but no definite brainstem or cord signal abnormality
* Echo: overall left ventricular systolic function is severely depressed, with a small pericardial effusion and no signs of tamponade

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Maintenance of pressors and fluids
* Cooling protocol to complete 18-24 hours, then re-warming
* Repeat blood cultures and urine cultures
* Head imaging pending re-warming
* C-spine MRI pending re-warming
* Consideration of LP when warmed
* Trending of lactate levels
* Continue current respiratory settings
* Monitor fever curve and consider gallium scan if fever spikes again
* Continue aspirin and pravastatin per neurology
* Consider holter on discharge
* Appreciate and follow neuro rec
* Continue ASA, statin, and hold BB given hypotension
* Start insulin for hyperglycemia
* Nutrition consult for tube feeds
* Prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin and pneumoboots
* Access: peripherals, right femoral line
* Communication: family
* Code status: DNR/DNI
* Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis due to uncontrolled infection
* Organ dysfunction due to hypoperfusion
* Respiratory failure due to inadequate oxygenation or ventilation
* Cardiac arrest due to continued hypotension and cardiac dysfunction
* Neurological deterioration due to ongoing embolic strokes
* Metabolic acidosis due to inadequate buffering or respiratory compensation
* Hyperglycemia due to inadequate insulin therapy
* Hypothyroidism due to adrenal nodules or thyroid dysfunction
* Adrenal insufficiency due to prolonged steroid use

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve his clinical outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old man admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of fevers and hypotension. He has a history of coronary artery disease, and was found unresponsive and pulseless, requiring resuscitation. He was diagnosed with embolic hemorrhagic strokes, and was started on cooling protocol, EEG, and CT of the head. He is currently being supported on levophed and fluids, and has been prescribed vancomycin, zosyn, and other medications. His vital signs are stable, but he has a fever of 101.1°F, and his lactate level is elevated at 5.1 mmol/L.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated lactate level may indicate sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death if not treated promptly.
2. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and the presence of a pericardial effusion may indicate a high risk of recurrent cardiac arrest.
3. Stroke: The patient's embolic hemorrhagic strokes may lead to further neurological complications, such as increased intracranial pressure, brain edema, and seizures.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hyperventilation and elevated lactate level may indicate respiratory failure, which can lead to further complications, such as pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
5. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's elevated lactate level and metabolic acidosis may indicate a high risk of further complications, such as cardiac arrest and organ dysfunction.
6. Infection: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count may indicate an infection, which can lead to further complications, such as sepsis and organ dysfunction.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient's history of hypothyroidism may indicate a high risk of further complications, such as decreased cardiac function and increased risk of infection.
8. Adrenal Insufficiency: The patient's history of adrenal nodules and normal cortisol level may indicate a high risk of adrenal insufficiency, which can lead to further complications, such as decreased cardiac function and increased risk of infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely for signs of sepsis, cardiac arrest, stroke, respiratory failure, metabolic acidosis, infection, hypothyroidism, and adrenal insufficiency.
2. Continue to administer antibiotics and antiviral medications as prescribed.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust therapy as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose level and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Consider consulting with a neurologist and a cardiologist to further evaluate the patient's condition and develop a comprehensive treatment plan.
7. Consider performing a CT or MRI scan of the head and spine to further evaluate the patient's stroke and potential complications.
8. Consider performing a bone marrow biopsy to evaluate the patient's bone marrow function and potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   #Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: The first documented rhythm
   was PEA.  patient was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing CPR and
   NaHCO3 and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome
   during the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause.  Lactate during the code was 8.1.  he is currently being
   supported on levophed and fluids.  CE was elevated as expected, but not
   down trending.  He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of
   head.  Had Femoral line with 1 postive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was started
   on [**3-25**]. Was cooled and then rewarmed.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated starting with neo
   - repeat LENIs to rule out possible PE contributing to event
   -f/u bld, urine cx
   -head imaging pending weaning of one pressor
   -c-spine MRI
   -consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate (presistently elevated to 5 and falling today to 2.2
   ..
   #Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   #Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.29/30/79.  likely due to cardiac
   disfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to pressors
   and cooling
   - cont. cooling protocol
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated after re-warming starting with
   neo
   .
   #Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP
   - d/c acyclovir
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   #embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   -start insulin
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right femoral line
   # Communication: family
   # Code: DNR/DNI
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old man admitted with fevers and hypotension, later diagnosed with embolic hemorrhagic strokes, and found unresponsive, asystolic, and pulseless. He was resuscitated and currently undergoing cooling protocol and pressor support.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: HR 75 bpm, BP 94/50 mmHg, RR 21 inspirations per minute, SpO2 98%.
* Respiratory support: on ventilator with CPAP/PSV mode, set VT 500 mL, PS 8 cmH2O, PEEP 8 cmH2O, FiO2 50%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 5 mmHg, total in/out fluid balance 4,930 mL/621 mL.
* Laboratory results:
	+ WBC 28.8 K/uL
	+ Hct 31.1%
	+ Plt 147 K/uL
	+ Cr 1.8 mg/dL
	+ TCO2 15 mmol/L
	+ Glucose 297 mg/dL
	+ Other labs: PT/PTT/INR 16.7/36.9/1.5, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T 337/19/0.06, ALT/AST 29/74, Alk Phos/T Bili 138/1.3, Lactic Acid 2.8 mmol/L, Albumin 1.6 g/dL, LDH 684 IU/L, Ca++ 7.6 mg/dL, Mg++ 2.0 mg/dL, PO4 5.4 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Continued hypotension and hemodynamic instability, potentially leading to organ dysfunction or failure.
2. Respiratory failure, requiring further adjustments to ventilator settings or consideration of alternative respiratory support modalities.
3. Metabolic acidosis, which may be exacerbated by cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow, and increased afterload.
4. Fevers of unknown origin, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
5. Hypoalbuminemia, which may contribute to intravascular volume and pressure problems.
6. Embolic stroke, which may require continued aspirin and pravastatin therapy, as well as consideration of holter monitoring and neurologic follow-up.
7. Hyperglycemia, which may require further insulin therapy and glycemic control measures.
8. Chronic kidney disease, stage III, which may require ongoing monitoring and management.
9. Potential for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP prophylaxis, which may require further evaluation and treatment.

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and his disposition is ICU pending clinical improvement.

   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development

   pulseless, s/p resusciation.

   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated starting with neo
   - repeat LENIs to rule out possible PE contributing to event
   - f/u bld, urine cx
   - Brain and C-spine MRI today
   - consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.38/28/111. likely due to
   cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to
   pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .

   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   # embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   -start insulin
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right IJ CVL, R A-line

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), admitted with fevers and hypotension, and has since developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, and in pulseless arrest. He was resuscitated and is currently undergoing extensive workup for fever of unknown origin (FUO). The patient is still requiring pressor support, has been weaned off neosynephrine overnight, and is being monitored for potential pulmonary embolism (PE) contributing to the event.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Complications:
	* Respiratory acidosis due to pressor support and cooling.
	* Pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged intubation.
2. Cardiovascular Complications:
	* Cardiac dysfunction and poor forward flow due to pressor support and cooling.
	* Hypotension due to sepsis, cardiac dysfunction, or medication.
	* Arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalance or medication.
3. Neurological Complications:
	* Stroke or embolic stroke due to cardiac or peripheral emboli.
	* Neurological sequelae due to hypoxia or hypoperfusion during cardiac arrest.
	* Seizures due to electrolyte imbalance or medication.
4. Metabolic Complications:
	* Metabolic acidosis due to cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow, or pressor support.
	* Hyperglycemia due to stress response or medication.
	* Hypoalbuminemia due to renal disease or poor nutrition.
5. Infectious Complications:
	* Sepsis due to undiagnosed infection.
	* Bacteremia or fungemia due to central line or peripheral catheter.
6. Hematological Complications:
	* Thrombocytopenia due to sepsis or medication.
	* Leukopenia or neutropenia due to sepsis or chemotherapy.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulcer or medication.
	* Pancreatitis due to hyperglycemia or medication.

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications. Further evaluation and treatment are necessary to address the underlying causes of the patient's condition and prevent further deterioration.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   #Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: The first documented rhythm
   was PEA.  patient was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing CPR and
   NaHCO3 and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome
   during the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause.  Lactate during the code was 8.1.  he is currently being
   supported on levophed and fluids.  CE was elevated as expected, but not
   down trending.  He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of
   head.  Had Femoral line with 1 postive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was started
   on [**3-25**]. Was cooled and then rewarmed.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated starting with neo
   - repeat LENIs to rule out possible PE contributing to event
   -f/u bld, urine cx
   -head imaging pending weaning of one pressor
   -c-spine MRI
   -consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate (presistently elevated to 5 and falling today to 2.2
   ..
   #Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   #Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.29/30/79.  likely due to cardiac
   disfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to pressors
   and cooling
   - cont. cooling protocol
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated after re-warming starting with
   neo
   .
   #Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP
   - d/c acyclovir
   .
   #embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   -start insulin
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right femoral line
   # Communication: family
   # Code: DNR/DNI
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old man with a history of CAD, admitted with fevers and hypotension, and later found unresponsive and pulseless with embolic hemorrhagic strokes. He was resuscitated and currently receives levophed and fluids. He is being supported with oxygen, ventillator, and pressors. His labs show elevated lactate, hyperglycemia, and abnormal kidney function. He has a history of hyperlipidemia, chronic kidney disease, and hypothyroidism.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac function is compromised due to the embolic hemorrhagic strokes, which may lead to further cardiac issues such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
2. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's lactate levels are elevated, which may indicate poor tissue perfusion, cardiac dysfunction, or sepsis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is on ventilator support, and weaning may be challenging due to his underlying cardiac and respiratory issues.
4. Sepsis: The patient's fever curve has trended down, but he may still be at risk for sepsis, particularly given his history of embolic hemorrhagic strokes.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, which may indicate insulin resistance or pancreatic dysfunction.
6. Chronic kidney disease: The patient's kidney function is compromised, which may lead to further kidney damage or failure.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient's thyroid function is abnormal, which may affect his overall metabolism and energy levels.
8. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's cortisol levels are normal, but he may still be at risk for adrenal insufficiency due to his underlying medical conditions.
9. Vascular complications: The patient's embolic hemorrhagic strokes may have caused vascular damage, which may lead to further vascular complications such as DVT or VAP.
10. Infection: The patient's fever and abnormal lab results may indicate an underlying infection, which needs to be investigated and treated promptly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-inch tall, 99.2 kg individual who has been admitted to the ICU for 24 hours. The patient has a history of increased liver enzymes due to Zocor (Simvastatin) and has undergone various medical interventions, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and insulin.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure of 94/50 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 21 inspirations per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 98% and their heart rhythm is sinus rhythm.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (28.8 K/uL), elevated lactate dehydrogenase (684 IU/L), and elevated liver enzymes (ALT: 29 IU/L, AST: 74 IU/L). The patient's blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine (Cr) levels are within normal limits.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including vasopressors, insulin, and antibiotics. They have also been receiving nutrition through a multi-lumen catheter and have had prophylactic measures taken to prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient's plan includes continued ICU care, glycemic control, and monitoring of their laboratory results. The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR), and their disposition is pending further evaluation.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and elevated liver enzymes may indicate the presence of an infection.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's use of vasopressors and insulin may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
3. Renal complications: The patient's elevated BUN and Cr levels may indicate the presence of renal complications, such as acute kidney injury (AKI).
4. Neurological complications: The patient's use of vasopressors and insulin may increase the risk of neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's use of antibiotics and vasopressors may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea or constipation.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's laboratory results and vital signs closely to identify any potential complications early and take prompt action to address them.

   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated starting with neo
   - repeat LENIs to rule out possible PE contributing to event
   - f/u bld, urine cx
   - Brain and C-spine MRI today
   - consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.38/28/111. likely due to
   cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to
   pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .

   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP

   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   # embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old man admitted with fevers and hypotension, currently undergoing an extensive workup for FUO with interval development of embolic hemorrhagic strokes. The patient has had a PEA arrest on [**3-25**] and was resuscitated.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Vital signs:
	+ HR: 75 bpm
	+ BP: 94/50 mmHg
	+ RR: 21 insp/min
	+ SpO2: 98%
* Hemodynamic monitoring:
	+ CVP: 5 mmHg
	+ Total In: 4,930 mL
	+ Total out: 621 mL
* Respiratory support:
	+ O2 delivery device: Endotracheal tube
	+ Ventilator mode: CPAP/PSV
	+ Vt (set): 500 mL
	+ PEEP: 8 cmH2O
	+ FiO2: 50%
* Laboratory results:
	+ WBC: 28.8 K/uL
	+ Hct: 31.1%
	+ Plt: 147 K/uL
	+ Cr: 1.8 mg/dL
	+ Glucose: 297 mg/dL
	+ Lactic acid: 2.8 mmol/L
* Medical conditions:
	+ CAD, native vessel
	+ Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules
	+ Hyperlipidemia
	+ Chronic kidney disease, stage III
	+ Hyperglycemia

The patient's potential medical complications are:

1. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac status is unstable, and he is still requiring pressor support.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is on ventilator support and has a respiratory acidosis.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a metabolic acidosis with a lactate level of 2.8 mmol/L.
4. Fever of unknown origin: The patient's fever curve has trended down, but the cause of the fever remains unknown.
5. Hypoalbuminemia: The patient's hypoalbuminemia may contribute to his intravascular volume and pressure problems.
6. Embolic stroke: The patient has had embolic hemorrhagic strokes, and his neurologic status is uncertain.
7. Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules: The patient's thyroid and adrenal function are abnormal, and he may require further evaluation and treatment.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose level is elevated, and he may require insulin therapy.
9. Chronic kidney disease, stage III: The patient's kidney function is abnormal, and he may require further evaluation and treatment.
10. DVT and VAP prophylaxis: The patient is at risk for DVT and VAP, and prophylactic measures are being taken.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue pressor support and wean as tolerated.
2. Repeat LENIs to rule out possible PE contributing to the event.
3. F/u blood and urine cultures.
4. Brain and C-spine MRI today.
5. Consider LP when stable.
6. F/up neuro recs.
7. Trend lactate.
8. Continue to monitor fever curve.
9. F/u CRP.
10. Consider LP.
11. Continue to wean from neosynephrine.
12. Continue aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
13. Consider holter on discharge.
14. Appreciate and follow neuro rec.
15. Continue ASA, statin.
16. Hold BB given hypotension.
17. Start insulin.
18. Nutrition consult for tube feeds.
19. Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots.
20. Access: peripherals, right IJ CVL, R A-line.
21. Communication: family.
22. Code: DNR/DNI.
23. Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old male who was admitted with a diagnosis of FUO (Fever of Unknown Origin) and later developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes. He was found unresponsive, asystolic, and pulseless, and was resuscitated. He was intubated due to respiratory failure and is currently being supported on levophed and fluids. He has a history of CAD, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. His current condition is critical, and he is being managed in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and his respiratory status is being closely monitored. He may be at risk for further respiratory deterioration if his underlying condition worsens.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of bacteremia, which may have contributed to his current condition. He may be at risk for further sepsis and organ dysfunction if his infection is not properly managed.
3. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's lactate levels are elevated, which may be a sign of poor tissue perfusion and cardiac dysfunction. He may be at risk for further metabolic acidosis if his cardiac function does not improve.
4. Cardiac Dysfunction: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he may be at risk for further cardiac deterioration if his condition worsens.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient has a history of embolic strokes, which may have caused permanent neurological damage. He may be at risk for further neurological complications, such as seizures or cerebral edema.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of bacteremia, and he may be at risk for further infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to his current condition. He may be at risk for further thyroid dysfunction if his condition worsens.
8. Adrenal Insufficiency: The patient's adrenal function is compromised, and he may be at risk for adrenal insufficiency if his condition worsens.
9. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient is NPO, and he may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as aspiration or gastrointestinal bleeding.
10. Skin Complications: The patient has a history of skin lesions, and he may be at risk for further skin complications, such as pressure ulcers or skin infections.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management in the ICU. He is at risk for a variety of medical complications, and his condition may worsen if not properly managed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, hypotension, and a history of cardiac arrest. The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a stable respiratory status. Cardiovascular-wise, the patient has a history of CAD and has experienced embolic hemorrhagic strokes, which may have contributed to the cardiac arrest.

The patient's neurological status is concerning, with evidence of multiple CVA, unclear etiology. The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely due to cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow, and increased afterload due to pressors and cooling.

The patient's lab results show:

* WBC: 28.8
* Hct: 31.1
* Plt: 147
* Cr: 1.8
* TCO2: 15
* Glucose: 297
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 16.7/36.9/1.5, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 337/19/0.06, ALT/AST: 29/74, Alk Phos/T Bili: 138/1.3, Lactic Acid: 2.8 mmol/L, Albumin: 1.6 g/dL, LDH: 684 IU/L, Ca++: 7.6 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.0 mg/dL, PO4: 5.4 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Vasopressors: Phenylephrine, Insulin, Vasopressin, Norepinephrine
* Antibiotics: Acyclovir, Vancomycin, Piperacillin
* Heparin Sodium (prophylaxis)
* Dextrose 50%
* Heparin Sodium (prophylaxis)
* Prophylaxis: DVT (boots), Stress ulcer (PPI), VAP (HOB elevation, mouth care, daily wake-up, RSBI)

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: continue mechanical ventilation and monitor SaO2
* Cardiac arrest: complete cooling protocol and continue current level of support
* Neurological: continue evaluation as outlined, considering multiple embolic events, such as endocarditis
* Bacteremia: continue antimicrobials
* Metabolic acidosis: likely due to cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow, and increased afterload due to pressors and cooling
* FUO: unclear etiology, evaluation in progress

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further neurological deterioration
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Respiratory failure
* Infection (bacteremia, VAP)
* Metabolic acidosis
* Endocarditis
* Embolic events
* Sepsis
* Multi-organ failure

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, lab results, and neurological status closely to adjust treatment plans accordingly and prevent potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated starting with neo
   - repeat LENIs to rule out possible PE contributing to event
   - f/u bld, urine cx
   - Brain and C-spine MRI today
   - consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.38/28/111. likely due to
   cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to
   pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), admitted to the ICU with fevers and hypotension. He experienced a cardiac arrest on [**3-25**] and was resuscitated. He has been undergoing an extensive workup for fever of unknown origin (FUO) with interval development of embolic hemorrhagic strokes. The patient is currently receiving pressor support and has been weaned off neosynephrine overnight. He has a femoral line with one positive blood culture, and a new radial line was placed on [**3-25**]. The patient's activity level has improved, and he is opening his eyes and moving his arms spontaneously.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is on ventilator support, and weaning is ongoing. He has a respiratory syncytial virus (RSBI) of 31, which is improving, but he may still require further respiratory support.
2. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient has a history of CAD and has experienced cardiac arrest. He is receiving pressor support, which may be contributing to cardiac dysfunction.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a metabolic acidosis with a pH of 7.39 and a lactate level of 3.0 mmol/L. This may be related to cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow, and increased afterload due to pressors and cooling.
4. Fever of unknown origin: The patient's fever curve has trended down, but he may still require further evaluation and treatment for FUO.
5. Hypoalbuminemia: The patient has hypoalbuminemia, which may be contributing to intravascular volume and pressure problems.
6. Embolic stroke: The patient has experienced embolic strokes, and he is receiving aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, and insulin therapy has been started.
8. Chronic kidney disease: The patient has chronic kidney disease, stage III, and is receiving IVF and repleting electrolytes.
9. Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.
10. Code status: The patient has a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) code status.

Overall, the patient is at risk for multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, cardiac dysfunction, metabolic acidosis, fever of unknown origin, hypoalbuminemia, embolic stroke, hyperglycemia, chronic kidney disease, and prophylaxis-related complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated, now vasopressor
   - f/u bld, urine cx
   - Brain and C-spine MRI today
   - consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.38/28/111. likely due to
   cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to
   pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   # embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   - insulin sliding scale
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right IJ CVL, R A-line
   # Communication: family
   # Code: DNR/DNI
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

**Patient Information**

* Age: 74 years old
* Chief Complaint: Fevers and hypotension
* Admission Date: March 6
* Current Status: Unresponsive, undergoing extensive workup for FUO (Fever of Unknown Origin) with interval development of embolic hemorrhagic strokes

**Vital Signs**

* Temperature: 36.7°C (98.1°F)
* Heart Rate: 67 beats per minute
* Blood Pressure: 93/48 mmHg
* Respiratory Rate: 21 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen Saturation: 97%
* Weight: 105.3 kg (admission: 89 kg)
* Height: 70 inches

**Lab Results**

* White Blood Cell Count: 28.8 K/uL (previous: 30.5 K/uL)
* Hemoglobin: 9.4 g/dL
* Platelet Count: 147 K/uL (previous: 109 K/uL)
* Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL
* Blood Urea Nitrogen: 67 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Potassium: 4.4 mEq/L, Sodium: 126 mEq/L, Chloride: 28.1%

**Medical Complications**

* PEA arrest on March 25, requiring resuscitation
* Embolic hemorrhagic strokes
* Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation
* Fevers of unknown origin
* Hypoalbuminemia (renal disease, poor PO)
* Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules
* Chronic kidney disease, stage III
* Hyperglycemia

**Treatment Plan**

* Maintain pressor support, wean as tolerated
* Continue antibiotics (vancomycin, zosyn)
* Monitor fever curve and consider LP (lumbar puncture)
* Continue respiratory support with CPAP/PSV
* Wean insulin sliding scale
* Continue nutrition support with IVF and tube feeds
* Monitor electrolytes and replete as needed
* Consider holter on discharge for cardiac monitoring

**Potential Medical Complications**

* Development of sepsis or septic shock
* Worsening of metabolic acidosis
* Increased risk of bleeding due to embolic hemorrhagic strokes
* Further cardiac dysfunction or arrhythmias
* Development of respiratory failure or worsening of respiratory status
* Worsening of kidney function or development of acute kidney injury
* Increased risk of infections due to immunosuppression
* Development of further electrolyte imbalances or hyperglycemia

**Code Status**

* DNR (do not resuscitate)

**Disposition**

* ICU pending clinical improvement

   Monitor UO, BUN, creatinine.
   HYPONATREMIA -- total body water overloaded.  Would check serum/urine
   osmoles, urine electrolytes.  Would provide NS constant infusion,
   monitor serial Na.

   glucose <150.
   FUO
 unclear etiology.  Evaluation in progress.  Currently without

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure following a cardiac arrest. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and is currently stable on current settings. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, and has undergone an extensive workup for fever of unknown origin (FUO) with interval development of embolic hemorrhagic strokes.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate of 86 beats per minute, blood pressure of 112/55 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 99% on 40% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2). He is receiving vasopressin and vasopressors, and has been tapered to two agents.

The patient's physical examination is notable for a soft, non-tender abdomen, and bilateral lower extremity edema. He is unable to stand, and has no muscle wasting. His skin is warm and has no rash or jaundice.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 28.8, hemoglobin of 9.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 147 K/uL. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 13 mEq/L, and creatinine is 2.1 mg/dL. His lactate level is 3.0 mmol/L, and his glucose level is 126 mg/dL.

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and is at risk for further respiratory decline.
2. Sepsis: The patient has bacteremia, and is at risk for further septic complications.
3. Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal insufficiency, and is at risk for further renal decline.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a history of metabolic acidosis, and is at risk for further acidosis.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, and is at risk for hypoglycemia.
6. Infection: The patient has bacteremia, and is at risk for further infection.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient has had a cardiac arrest, and is at risk for further cardiovascular instability.

The patient's current plan includes:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor SaO2.
2. Continue antimicrobials for bacteremia.
3. Monitor UO, BUN, and creatinine for renal function.
4. Provide NS constant infusion and monitor serial Na for hyponatremia.
5. Maintain glucose <150 mg/dL.
6. Continue evaluation for FUO.
7. Monitor for signs of infection and cardiovascular instability.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a complex medical condition. The patient's 24-hour events include a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan, removal of an arterial line, and initiation of various medications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.6°C (96°F), heart rate of 82 beats per minute, blood pressure of 105/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's laboratory results indicate a white blood cell count of 28.8 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin level of 9.6 g/dL, and platelet count of 147 x 10^9/L. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated lactate level of 2.7 mmol/L.

The patient has a number of medical problems, including electrolyte and fluid disorder, respiratory failure, shock, altered mental status, hypothermia, and fever. The patient's ICU care plan includes nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and fever may indicate sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
3. Shock: The patient's shock may progress to cardiogenic or septic shock, leading to cardiovascular instability and organ failure.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte disorder may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and neurological dysfunction.
5. Infection: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count may indicate an infection, which can spread to other parts of the body and lead to sepsis.
6. Organ dysfunction: The patient's altered mental status and hypothermia may indicate organ dysfunction, which can lead to multi-organ failure.
7. Venous thromboembolism: The patient's prophylaxis for DVT may not be effective, leading to venous thromboembolism and potentially life-threatening complications.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical condition requiring close monitoring and management. The patient's potential medical complications are numerous, and it is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary to prevent and manage these complications.

   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resusciation.
   .
   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
 dc vancomycin as coag neg
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated, now only on levophed
   - f/u bld, urine cx
   - f/u Brain and C-spine MRI today
   - consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Thrombocytopoenia
 platelets today are 72, stepwise decline from 201
   on [**3-25**]^th. Most likely possibility is drug related (zosyn vs
   heparin vs vancomycin), could also be DIC (unlikely given stable HCT)
   or TTP. Unclear if this affects his prognosis
   - trend
   - DC heparin, vancomycin
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.38/28/111. likely due to
   cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to
   pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   # embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   - insulin sliding scale
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right IJ CVL, R A-line
   # Communication: family
   # Code: DNR/DNI
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development

   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.
   - vancomycin, zosyn
 dc vancomycin as coag neg
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated, now only on levophed
   - f/u bld, urine cx
   - f/u Brain and C-spine MRI today
   - consider LP when stable
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   .
   # Thrombocytopoenia
 platelets today are 72, stepwise decline from 201
   on [**3-25**]^th. Most likely possibility is drug related (zosyn vs
   heparin vs vancomycin), could also be DIC (unlikely given stable HCT)
   or TTP. Unclear if this affects his prognosis
   - trend
   - DC heparin, vancomycin
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1
 last abg 7.38/28/111. likely due to
   cardiac dysfunction, poor forward flow + increased afterload due to
   pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CRP
   -- consider LP
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   # embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .

   .

   .

   .

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) who was admitted with fevers and hypotension. He developed embolic hemorrhagic strokes, became unresponsive, and had a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest. He was resuscitated and has been in the ICU since then. The patient's current status is:

* Hemodynamically unstable, requiring pressor support
* Respiratory support with mechanical ventilation
* Fever of unknown origin, trending down
* Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation
* Thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 72
* Hypoalbuminemia, likely contributing to intravascular volume and pressure problems
* Embolic stroke, with ongoing aspirin and pravastatin therapy
* Hypothyroidism and adrenal nodules, with ongoing thyroid and adrenal function monitoring
* Chronic kidney disease, stage III, with stable renal function
* Hyperglycemia, managed with insulin sliding scale

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
2. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as cardiac dysfunction and respiratory failure.
3. Hypoalbuminemia: The patient's hypoalbuminemia may contribute to intravascular volume and pressure problems, which may worsen his hemodynamic instability.
4. Embolic stroke: The patient's embolic stroke may lead to further neurological complications, such as increased intracranial pressure, cerebral edema, and seizures.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar nonketotic coma, and cardiovascular disease.
6. Thromboembolic events: The patient's thrombocytopenia and hypoalbuminemia may increase his risk of thromboembolic events, such as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
7. Infection: The patient's fever of unknown origin may be a sign of a underlying infection, which may worsen if not treated promptly.
8. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient's cardiac dysfunction may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as cardiac arrest, cardiogenic shock, and heart failure.

   74 yom CAD, admitted [**3-6**] workup for FUO with interval development of

   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- intubated in context of cardiac arrest.  Stable

   Radiographic evidence for pleural effusions, bilateral.  Reasonable gas
   exchange.  Main obstacle to extubation currently altered mental status.
   s/p CARDIAC ARREST
 asystole as initial rhythm, may have experienced

   of vasopressors, monitor BP, maintain MAP >60 mmHg.

   bilateral.  Possible Continue evaluation as outlined.   Consider
   multiple embolic events, such as endocarditis.  Awaiting final read of
   MRI of spine to assess for spinal cord lesion.  CSF analysis.

   Continue antimicrobials.
   THROMBOCYTOPENIA -- dramatic decline.
   METABOLIC ACIDOSIS --  Notable for prior lactate of 5.1, now
   improving.  Would repeat.
   RENAL FAILURE -- acute on chronic insufficiency.  Non-oliguric.
   Monitor UO, BUN, creatinine.
   HYPONATREMIA -- total body water overloaded.  Would check serum/urine
   osmoles, urine electrolytes.  Would provide NS constant infusion,
   monitor serial Na.  Change meds to NS.
   HYPERGLYCEMIA -- improved control.  Now off insulin infusion.  Maintain
   glucose <150.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT -- initiate TF.
   FUO
 unclear etiology.  Evaluation in progress.  Currently without

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old male admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and sepsis. The patient's condition is critical, and he is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated.

The patient's medical history is significant for cardiac arrest, embolic hemorrhagic strokes, and sepsis. He has a history of coronary artery disease and is currently on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 35.8°C (96.4°F)
* Heart rate: 95 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 110/62 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Norepinephrine infusion at 0.18 mcg/kg/min

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* General appearance: Well-nourished, no acute distress
* Eyes: PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light)
* Head, ears, nose, and throat: Normocephalic, no poor dentition, endotracheal tube
* Cardiovascular: Normal pulse, no murmurs
* Respiratory: Clear breath sounds, no wheezes or rhonchi
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: Right lower extremity edema absent, left lower extremity edema absent
* Skin: Warm, no rash or jaundice
* Neurologic: Non-purposeful movement, decreased tone

The patient's laboratory results are:

* White blood cell count: 28.8-30.5 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 31.1-29.7%
* Platelet count: 147-109 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.0-2.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 14-17 mg/dL
* Glucose: 159-220 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.7 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.6 g/dL
* LDH: 684 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.5 mg/dL

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor SaO2
* Tolerate net weaning of vasopressors and monitor blood pressure
* Continue antimicrobials for bacteremia
* Monitor for thrombocytopenia and bleeding
* Monitor for metabolic acidosis and provide supportive care
* Monitor for renal failure and provide supportive care
* Monitor for hypoglycemia and provide supportive care
* Initiate total parenteral nutrition (TPN)
* Continue evaluation for fever of unknown origin (FUO)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, respiratory distress syndrome, or worsening of lung function
* Cardiac arrest: Cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or worsening of cardiac function
* Sepsis: Worsening of septic shock, development of multi-organ failure, or death
* Thrombocytopenia: Bleeding or bleeding complications
* Metabolic acidosis: Worsening of acidosis, development of lactic acidosis, or death
* Renal failure: Worsening of renal failure, development of acute kidney injury, or death
* Hypoglycemia: Worsening of hypoglycemia, development of hyperglycemia, or death

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan as necessary to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and multiple organ dysfunction. The patient's condition is complex and multifaceted, with several potential medical complications arising from his underlying illnesses and treatments.

1. Respiratory failure: The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a reasonable gas exchange and radiographic evidence of pleural effusions. The main obstacle to extubation is altered mental status.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient experienced cardiac arrest, with asystole as the initial rhythm, and may have had pulseless electrical activity (PEA). He has undergone cooling protocol and is currently receiving supportive care.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is attributed to sepsis, and he is tolerating net weaning of vasopressors, with a goal of maintaining a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 60 mmHg.
4. Neurological complications: The patient has evidence of multiple cerebral vascular accidents (CVAs), with unclear etiology, and possible embolic events, including endocarditis. He is awaiting final read of MRI of the spine to assess for spinal cord lesions and CSF analysis.
5. Bacteremia: The patient has bacteremia attributed to line placement during cardiac arrest, and is receiving antimicrobial therapy.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a dramatic decline in platelet count, with a possibility of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), medication effect, or consumptive coagulopathy.
7. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has notable metabolic acidosis, with a prior lactate level of 5.1, which is now improving.
8. Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal insufficiency, with non-oliguric kidney injury.
9. Hyponatremia: The patient has total body water overload, with a possibility of hyponatremia, and is receiving constant infusion of normal saline (NS) to monitor serial sodium levels.
10. Hyperglycemia: The patient has improved glucose control, with a goal of maintaining glucose levels less than 150 mg/dL.
11. Nutritional support: The patient requires initiation of total parenteral nutrition (TF).
12. Fever of unknown origin (FUO): The patient's FUO remains unclear, with an ongoing evaluation in progress.

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Nutrition: Initiate TF
* Glycemic control: Maintain glucose levels less than 150 mg/dL
* Lines: Multi-lumen catheter for central venous access
* Prophylaxis: Stress ulcer prophylaxis with PPI, DVT prophylaxis with boots, and VAP prophylaxis with HOB elevation, mouth care, and RSBI
* Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)

The patient's critical illness requires close monitoring and management of his complex medical condition, with a focus on preventing potential complications and optimizing his care plan.

   74 y.o. man with pmh CAD, admitted [**3-6**] with fevers and hypotension,
   currently undergoing extensive workup for FUO with interval development
   of embolic hemorrhagic strokes, found unresponsive, asystolic, and
   pulseless, s/p resuscitation.
   .
   # Unresponsiveness/Hemodynamic instability: PEA arrest on [**3-25**].  Patient
   was coded for roughly 20 minutes, undergoing chest compressions, NaHCO3
   and epinephrine.  Unclear etiology, though patient had prodrome during
   the day of new weakness and upgoing babinski, along with urinary
   retention, which then progressed to respiratory alkalosis of unknown
   cause. He was put on cooling protocol s/p Echo, EEG, CT of head
   (negative for acute bleed).  He had a femoral line with 1 positive BCx
 GPC - New RIJ was placed on [**3-25**].  He is still requiring pressor
   support, though able to be weaned off of neosynephrine overnight.  LP
   done.
   Mental status has improved and intermittently follows commands.
   - vancomycin, zosyn both discontinued per ID
   - wean pressors, now only on levophed
   - f/u bld, urine cx, LP cx
   - f/up neuro recs
   - trend lactate
   - CSF cultures, HSV, VZV, EBV, TB
   - TEE today to look for potential source of emboli
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia
 platelets today are 72, stepwise decline from 201
   on [**3-25**]^th. Most likely possibility is drug related (zosyn vs
   heparin vs vancomycin), could also be DIC (unlikely given stable HCT)
   or TTP. Unclear if this affects his prognosis
   - trend
   - DC heparin, vancomycin, famotidine
   - get DIC/TTP labs for now
   - guaiac stool
   - BMT for BM biopsy results
   .
   # Respiratory status: oxygenating well, improving RSBI
   - on vent continue to wean
   - plan to diurese as tolerates
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation: notable
   for initial lactate of 5.1 likely due to cardiac dysfunction, poor
   forward flow + increased afterload due to pressors and cooling
   - maintain pressors, wean as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers of unknown origin - fever curve has trended down with T max of
   100.1. Per discussions with ID, would not pursue gallium scan unless
   spikes a true fever. Continues to be off antibiotics. Per primary team,
   ID recomends gallium scan if he spikes another true fever, Rheum does
   not feel this ios consistent with vasculitis or lupus.  Endocrine team
   feels that he is adrenally sufficient and would not supplement with
   steroids at this point. Per hematology, bone marrow with hypercellular
   marrow and not myeloma.
   -- Continue to monitor fever curve
   -- f/u CSF results
   -- TEE
   .
   # Hypoalbuminemia: renal disease, Poor PO. Likely contributes to
   intravascular volume and pressure problems
   .
   # embolic stroke: continuing aspirin and pravastatin per neurology.
   -consider holter on discharge
   -appreciate and follow neuro rec
   -question if need rheum consult
   .
   * Hypothyroidism/Adrenal nodules - Per endo, feel that while he did not
   have a rise in cortisol by 8 points, still feel that he does not need
   steroids given his normal AM cortisol. Additionally, feel that he has
   sick euthyroid and would not give thyroid replacement at this time.
   -- Will need f/u TFTs in [**2-19**] weeks
   -- Will need endocrine follow up.
   .
   * CAD, native vessel - No chest pain.
   -- Continue ASA, statin
   -- Hold BB given hypotension
   .
   * Hyperlipidemia - Statin as above
   .
   * Chronic kidney disease, stage III - Stable.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   - insulin sliding scale
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, nutrition consult for tube feeds
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots
   # Access: peripherals, right IJ CVL, R A-line
   # Communication: family
   # Code: DNR/DNI
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
